update.description:
In the spirit of pull request #1315 by @iche033 , I am adding some more protobuf -> SDF conversion functions, along with tests. The new functions are all covered, though not with 100% branch coverage.

* VisualToSDF
* MaterialToSDF
* ConvertShaderType x2

I also used the `VisualToSDF` function in `LinkToSDF`.

I also added some modification to other tests in `UNIT_msgs_TEST`. I can split that out to a separate pull request if it's too distracting. For the refactoring, I recommend the side-by-side diff view.

After this is merged:

* JointToSDF
* ModelToSDF
* and then some code changes that actually use these convenient functions
update.title: Add msgs::VisualToSDF, MaterialToSDF, and ConvertShaderType

content.raw:
* [jenkins test coverage](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/249/clover-report/_var_lib_jenkins_workspace_gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64_gazebo_gazebo_msgs/msgs_cc.html)
* [jenkins trusty is happy](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/478/)

EDIT: updated the coverage link to point to the msgs.cc file
content.html:
• jenkins test coverage
  • jenkins trusty is happy

EDIT: updated the coverage link to point to the msgs.cc file

content.raw:
It's related to the machine that ran the test coverage. Currently the [gazebo-any-coverage jenkins job](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/) will use any machine running trusty that has GPU support enabled. There are two machines that match these criteria:

* [maria](http://build.osrfoundation.org/computer/maria.intel.trusty/) with Intel GPU
* [optimus](http://build.osrfoundation.org/computer/optimus.nv.trusty/) with nvidia GPU

Currently almost all of our tests are failing with the Intel GPU. @\_jrivero_ is leading the debugging effort to figure out why this is the case. The effect of this is that the coverage will look really bad (about 12%) with intel GPU, vs. around 40% on nvidia.

It used to be that coverage would only run on nvida machines, but the farm was really clogged with jobs, so I switched it to use any GPU. I will switch it back right now to nvidia until we fix the tests with intel.
content.html:
It's related to the machine that ran the test coverage. Currently the gazebo-any-coverage jenkins job will use any machine running trusty that has GPU support enabled. There are two machines that match these criteria:

  • maria with Intel GPU
  • optimus with nvidia GPU

Currently almost all of our tests are failing with the Intel GPU. @_jrivero_ is leading the debugging effort to figure out why this is the case. The effect of this is that the coverage will look really bad (about 12%) with intel GPU, vs. around 40% on nvidia.

It used to be that coverage would only run on nvida machines, but the farm was really clogged with jobs, so I switched it to use any GPU. I will switch it back right now to nvidia until we fix the tests with intel.

content.raw: The SDF documentation mentions `<split_impulse>` and `<split_impulse_penetration_threshold>` as [required](http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.5&elem=collision#bullet_split_impulse) elements for bullet.
content.html: The SDF documentation mentions <split_impulse> and <split_impulse_penetration_threshold> as required elements for bullet.

content.raw: I have a question about test coverage. I don't understand how it is being counted. For example, `rendering/Visual.cc` has a related unit test `rendering/Visual_TEST.cc`, but it shows as having 0/100 functions covered. And in fact, `Visual_TEST.cc` also seems to be [considered](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/249/clover-report/) a function that should be tested. Am I reading this wrong?
content.html: I have a question about test coverage. I don't understand how it is being counted. For example, rendering/Visual.cc has a related unit test rendering/Visual_TEST.cc, but it shows as having 0/100 functions covered. And in fact, Visual_TEST.cc also seems to be considered a function that should be tested. Am I reading this wrong?

content.raw: Passing back `result="unknown"` seems fine. Please document this in the header. Sending out a `gzerr` doesn't hurt, if you are so inclined.
content.html: Passing back result="unknown" seems fine. Please document this in the header. Sending out a gzerr doesn't hurt, if you are so inclined.

content.raw: Option 2 was what I was referring to. We don't have a constraint between shader type and normal map in the message or SDF, so we probably shouldn't create that constraint here.
content.html: Option 2 was what I was referring to. We don't have a constraint between shader type and normal map in the message or SDF, so we probably shouldn't create that constraint here.

content.raw: You don't have to change the other location (you might end up going down a rabbit  hole of changes).
content.html: You don't have to change the other location (you might end up going down a rabbit hole of changes).

content.raw: I figured this would help with finding errors. Any advice @nkoenig ?
content.html: I figured this would help with finding errors. Any advice @nkoenig ?

content.raw:
Ok, I'm just going to be extra verbose to make sure we're on the same page. Here's what I think the two options are:

1. Current code: check `has_normal_map()` only if `has_shader_type()` is true. This would drop the normal map name if the `shader_type` is not specified.

2. Your proposal: create the normal map regardless of the existence of `shader_type`. This would create the following:
~~~
<shader>
  <normal_map>data</normal_map>
</shader>
~~~
Without the type attribute specified, the [shader will default to "pixel"](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/cb779ddd18d4805e10a238afffde7e85426689ae/sdf/1.5/material.sdf?at=default#cl-19), so the sdf would become:
~~~
<shader type="pixel">
  <normal_map>data</normal_map>
</shader>
~~~
Does that sound right? Option 2 is fine for me.
content.html:
Ok, I'm just going to be extra verbose to make sure we're on the same page. Here's what I think the two options are:

  1. Current code: check has_normal_map() only if has_shader_type() is true. This would drop the normal map name if the shader_type is not specified.

  2. Your proposal: create the normal map regardless of the existence of shader_type. This would create the following:

<shader>
  <normal_map>data</normal_map>
</shader>

Without the type attribute specified, the shader will default to "pixel", so the sdf would become:

<shader type="pixel">
  <normal_map>data</normal_map>
</shader>

Does that sound right? Option 2 is fine for me.

content.raw: I based this `gzthrow` off of existing code in [msgs::VisualFromSDF](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/9b3dea9af2740ad0678f899c47b8aa17a953ceef/gazebo/msgs/msgs.cc?at=default#cl-856). Should we change that too?
content.html: I based this gzthrow off of existing code in msgs::VisualFromSDF. Should we change that too?

content.raw: Placing this `if` inside the check for `shader_type` could loose information. A normal map only makes sense if the shader type is set, but that relationship is not enforced via the message type or SDF.
content.html: Placing this if inside the check for shader_type could loose information. A normal map only makes sense if the shader type is set, but that relationship is not enforced via the message type or SDF.

content.raw: Can you mark this as a "/// \todo" if it is something that should be updated in the future?
content.html: Can you mark this as a "/// \todo" if it is something that should be updated in the future?

content.raw: We shouldn't throw an exception here. An error message is fine. You can add a comment to the function's doxygen that it will log an error, and return VERTEX if the shader type is not known.
content.html: We shouldn't throw an exception here. An error message is fine. You can add a comment to the function's doxygen that it will log an error, and return VERTEX if the shader type is not known.

content.raw: It seems a bit inconsistent that converting an unknown string into type throws an error but going the other way around something is returned with no error. Is this for backwards compatibility?
content.html: It seems a bit inconsistent that converting an unknown string into type throws an error but going the other way around something is returned with no error. Is this for backwards compatibility?

content.raw: Just out of curiosity, when is it recommended to use `gzthrow` instead of `gzerr`?
content.html: Just out of curiosity, when is it recommended to use gzthrow instead of gzerr?
